slides.mascot_explanation: Time for the movement investigation! Use your model arm to show how the muscles pull to bend it. Then, stand up and try moving in five different ways, like waving or squatting. For each movement, think about which joints are working, what kind of joint it is, and which muscles are helping you move. Write all your amazing findings in your notebook!

slides.text: Your body is an incredible machine. Over 200 bones and 600 muscles work together at hundreds of joints to let you move in countless ways. Tendons connect muscles to bones, ligaments connect bones to bones, and joints allow movement. This week we have discovered the framework and the engine that make your body move!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain how muscles and bones work together at joints, name three types of joints, and demonstrate understanding with their model arm?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you’ve just learned so much about your incredible body! You built a model and discovered how bones, muscles, and joints all work together like a super team to let you run, jump, and play. Remember how muscles pull on bones to make movement happen – your body is truly a fantastic machine!

parent_notes: The model arm is the highlight of this week's science sequence. It transforms an abstract concept into something tangible and memorable. The rubber band truly does mimic muscle action — it can only pull, not push, which demonstrates why muscles must work in pairs. Extend the learning by exploring more complex movements: walking involves dozens of muscles and joints working in sequence. This integrated understanding of body systems prepares children for more advanced biology. Keep the model to reference in future lessons about the body.

title: Multi-Color Relief Prints — Layering and Pattern Design
description: Children build on their printmaking skills by creating multi-color prints. They learn to layer colors by printing one design on top of another and experiment with creating patterns through repetition.
instructions:
1. Review Monday's relief printing technique.
2. Introduce layering: print one color, let it dry, then print a second color on top.
3. Demonstrate: print a background pattern in yellow. Let it dry briefly. Print a detailed design in blue on top.
4. Discuss registration: lining up the second print over the first.
5. Introduce pattern design: print the same stamp repeatedly to create a repeating pattern (like wallpaper or fabric).
6. Child plans a two-color print design on scratch paper first.
7. Create the foam plates (one for each color layer) and print.
8. Display finished multi-color prints.

slides.heading: Multi-Color Relief Prints
slides.mascot_explanation: This first slide is like the title page for our art adventure today! It tells us we're going to be making "Multi-Color Relief Prints" and learning how to put colors on top of each other, called "layering," and how to make cool designs by repeating them, which is called "pattern design."

items: 2 clean flat styrofoam trays per design
slides.setup_instructions: Cut flat centers from multiple styrofoam trays. Have 2-3 paint colors squeezed onto separate plates for rolling. Cover workspace generously — this is a messier project. Have a drying area set up. Demonstrate the layering technique before the child begins.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our supplies ready for this awesome project! We'll need two flat pieces of styrofoam for each picture we want to make, and a pencil to draw and carve our designs into them. We also need paint in two or three colors, a roller to spread the paint, some paper to print on, and newspaper to protect our tables because printmaking can get a little messy!

slides.text: 'On Tuesday, we made single-color prints. Today we are going to the NEXT level — MULTI-COLOR prints! Real printmakers often use several layers of color. Each color has its own printing plate, and they are printed one on top of the other.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember yesterday when we made those cool prints? Well, today we're going to make them even more amazing by using *two* colors instead of just one! Real artists who make prints often use different plates for each color and stack them up to make their pictures even more interesting.

slides.text: Demonstrate: 'First, I carve a simple background design on Plate 1 — maybe circles or stripes. I print it in yellow. While it dries for a moment, I carve a more detailed design on Plate 2 — maybe a flower. Then I print the flower in blue RIGHT ON TOP of the yellow print. Two colors, one beautiful print!'
slides.mascot_explanation: So, here's how we make a two-color picture. First, we'll carve a simple pattern, like stripes, into one foam plate and print it with yellow paint. While that's drying for just a minute, we'll carve a different, more detailed picture, like a flower, into the second foam plate and print it with blue paint right on top of the yellow.

slides.text: 'The tricky part is REGISTRATION — lining up the second print over the first. A simple trick: mark the corners of your paper position with pencil dots. That way, you place the paper in the same spot each time. Professional printmakers use special marks called registration marks.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, this is a super important trick called "registration" – it's all about making sure our second color lines up perfectly over the first one. We can put little pencil dots on our paper to show us exactly where to put the paper each time we print, so our second picture lands right where we want it.

slides.text: 'You can also create PATTERNS by repeating the same print over and over. Stamp your design in rows across a larger paper to make a repeating pattern — like wallpaper or fabric. Try rotating your stamp, alternating colors, or flipping it for variety.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Guess what? We can also make really neat patterns, like the ones you see on wrapping paper or cool shirts, by using our stamp over and over again! You can print the same design in rows, or try turning your stamp different ways or using different colors to make your pattern super unique.

slides.prompt: Plan a two-color layered print on scratch paper first. Decide: what will the background layer look like? What will the top layer add? Carve your two plates, then print. Make at least 3 layered prints, experimenting with color combinations. Then create a pattern by stamping your favorite design repeatedly across a larger piece of paper. Try at least 2 different arrangements.
slides.mascot_explanation: Alright, it's your turn to create! First, grab some scratch paper and plan out your two-color picture – what will your background look like, and what will the second layer add? Then, carve your foam plates and start printing, trying out different color mixes! After that, pick your favorite design and make a big pattern by stamping it lots of times on a bigger paper.

slides.text: You have explored one of the oldest and most versatile art forms in the world. Printmaking combines planning, design, and technique. Your multi-color prints show how layers of color create depth and interest. Professional artists, textile designers, and book illustrators all use these same principles. Keep experimenting with your printing plates!
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create multi-color layered prints using registration, design repeating patterns, and explain the printmaking process?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it! You've learned how to be a printmaker, just like artists who have been making prints for thousands of years! You made amazing layered pictures with two colors and created cool repeating patterns, showing how different colors can make art look so interesting and deep.

parent_notes: Multi-color printing requires patience and planning — excellent skills for children to develop. The registration concept (aligning layers) is challenging but rewarding. Do not expect perfection; slight misalignment creates interesting artistic effects. Pattern creation connects to math (repetition, symmetry, tessellation). Children's prints make wonderful gifts — consider using them for greeting cards, wrapping paper, or framed art. This project can extend over multiple sessions if the child is engaged. The connection to industrial printing (newspapers, books, textiles) ties back to the Industrial Revolution history studies.
